rogel.io.fopl.proof

Class HornClause

  • java.lang.Object
    • rogel.io.fopl.proof.HornClause
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Expression

    public class HornClause
extends java.lang.Object
implements Expression
    A HornClause is a clause with at most one positive (i.e. unnegated) literal. A HornClause has many forms, which have different names. Although they are typically represented as a disjunction of literals, the explanation that follows represents them as implications (the underlying formulae are logically equivalent):
    • A HornClause of the form u <- p ^ q ^ r is called a definite clause.
    • A HornClause of the form u is called a fact.
    • A HornClause of the form p ^ q ^ r is called a goal clause.
    Author:
    recardona

      HornClause(Predicate fact)
      Constructs a HornClause with just one positive literal.
      HornClause(Predicate consequent, Formula antecedent)
      Constructor for a HornClause with one positive literal and a goal clause (which represents implicitly disjunctive negated literals).

    • Constructor Detail

      • HornClause

        public HornClause(Predicate fact)
        Constructs a HornClause with just one positive literal. This is a HornClause fact.
        Parameters:
        fact - The Predicate this HornClause asserts.

      • HornClause

        public HornClause(Predicate consequent,
          Formula antecedent)
        Constructor for a HornClause with one positive literal and a goal clause (which represents implicitly disjunctive negated literals).
        Parameters:
        consequent - The Predicate this HornClause aims to prove.
        antecedent - The goal Formula portion of this HornClause.

    • Method Detail

      • isDefiniteClause

        public boolean isDefiniteClause()
        Returns true if this HornClause is a definite clause. A HornClause is definite if it has both an antecedent and a consequent.
        Returns:
        true if this HornClause is a definite clause.

      • isFact

        public boolean isFact()
        Returns true if this HornClause is a fact. A HornClause is a fact if it has a consequent with no antecedent.
        Returns:
        true if this HornClause is a fact.

      • isGoalClause

        public boolean isGoalClause()
        Returns true if this HornClause is a goal clause. A HornClause is a goal if it has an antecedent with no consequent.
        Returns:
        true if this HornClause is a goal clause.

      • getAntecedent

        public Formula getAntecedent()
        Gets this HornClause's antecedent if it exists, null otherwise. The antecedent represents the body of the HornClause. e.g. for a HornClause u <- p ^ q ^ r, the antecedent would be p ^ q ^ r.
        Returns:
        the antecedent Formula.

      • getConsequent

        public Predicate getConsequent()
        Gets this HornClause's consequent. The antecedent represents the assertion of the HornClause. e.g. for a HornClause u <- p ^ q ^ r, the consequent would be u.
        Returns:
        the consequent Predicate.

      • replaceVariables

        Description copied from interface: Expression
        Replaces any Variable in this Expression with its binding in the Substitution, if it exists.

      • standardizeVariablesApart

        public Expression standardizeVariablesApart(java.util.HashMap<Variable,Variable> newVariables)
        Description copied from interface: Expression
        Replaces the Variables in this Expression with new copies of the Variable that have the same name. The copies are the Variables that have been standardized.
        Specified by:
        standardizeVariablesApart in interface Expression
        Parameters:
        newVariables - The set of Variables that have been copied thus far.
        Returns:
        an Expression with standardized Variables.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a String representation of this HornClause, which is a Prolog-style String.
        • For facts, the String appears as consequent.
        • For goal clauses, the String appears as :- antecedent.
        • For definite clauses, the String appears as consequent :- antecedent.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a String representation of this object.
